Using the StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration

You can export tasks to StarTeam from Microsoft Project. Before you accomplish this, however, however, you must install both Microsoft Project and the StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration. Then you must run the macros necessary to place a StarTeam menu on the Microsoft Project menu bar. See Setting Up StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration.

To take advantage of StarTeam and Microsoft Project interoperability:

  1. Open a Microsoft Project file (other than StarTeam.mpp). It is best not to use a consolidated project, which has other project files as subprojects, or a linked project, which has links to tasks in other project files.

  2. Determine the server from which you will import users and the StarTeam project, view, and folder to which you will export Microsoft Project tasks. This information usually comes from an administrator or team leader. See Accessing StarTeam Servers.

  3. Import StarTeam users to add as resources in the Microsoft Project file. For additional information, see Synchronizing Users.

  4. Add tasks to the project.

  5. Export tasks from Microsoft Project to a folder in a StarTeam project view. Tasks created in Microsoft Project can be exported to more than one StarTeam project, view, or folder; however, no individual task can be exported to more than one StarTeam location. Tasks can be re-exported to change their initial location. See Exporting Microsoft Project Tasks to StarTeam.

  6. Import work records from StarTeam to update your Microsoft Project (.mpp) file. If new users are added to StarTeam and work on exported tasks, those users can be imported as resources during the work-import process. See Importing StarTeam Work Records to Microsoft Project.

  7. Synchronize the exported tasks in StarTeam so that the StarTeam tasks reflect any changes to the corresponding tasks in Microsoft Project. Tasks created in the StarTeam Task component are ignored by StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration. See Synchronizing Tasks.
